instruction: Eliza Raven. Hello Dr. Balis. I'm glad to make your acquaintance.
output: And I am glad to make yours. Will you please have a seat?

instruction: Oh yes, thank you.
output: I got a message from some man that you wanted to see me, but he wasn't very specific.  So what would you like to talk about, Ms. Raven?

instruction: Please call me Eliza, or Liz if you prefer. I can talk about anything you wish.
output: Okay Eliza, why don't we start with why you're here?

instruction: Oh, well Luke called in the appointment. He said it was high time for me to see someone who can tell me what is wrong with me.
output: And Luke is...?

instruction: Luke's my fiancé.  I didn't mean that I didn't want to come too.  I wanted to. I've wanted to for a very long time. I just...couldn't get up the nerve to call.
output: You were nervous about calling me?

instruction: This is really embarrassing.
output: We can switch subjects if you like.

instruction: No, no, no. I'll talk. I guess I've always had this fear of calling someone for the first time. Like in high school, boys would give me their number, but I could never get up the nerve to call them. So I just gave them my number the next day and waited for them to call me. If they called me, then I could call them back. It's like that with the phone company, and other places that I owe money to. I just can't get up the nerve to call and make arrangements if I am going to be late on a payment. It's just so frustrating!
output: I can see how that would be frustrating. Here's some tissue if you need it.

instruction: No, no, no. I'll be okay. I just need to catch my breath.
output: We can wait until you're ready.

instruction: Okay, now I feel stupid. God! I am so stupid. It's not fair! Nobody else ever feels like this.
output: Actually, I know a lot of people who are apprehensive about calling people they don't know on the telephone. You don't need to feel stupid.

instruction: Thanks for being so nice to me and I appreciate your sympathy. But I just can't believe that you personally know anyone like me. I'm so screwed up.
output: I'd like to get to the root of those feelings.

instruction: I don't know where the root is.
output: We'll work together to get there, okay?

instruction: Sure. So you are on my side?
output: Yes.

instruction: Good. I feel so much better knowing that. I figured we'd end up talking about my mother; I never figured that I would disclose one of my biggest secrets.
output: Your apprehension on the telephone is a secret?  Does your family know about it?

instruction: Yes. It's a very big secret. My family knows, and my fiancé Luke of course, but no one else. Luke doesn't understand it though. He gets very frustrated with me when I can't call someone. I get scared and he just makes it worse. He's not very sympathetic about it. Usually, he'll tell me I have to call someone, and then I'll start to get all panicky. And then he'll give me the "It's part of being an adult so why don't you grow up" speech. Usually I'll break down in tears and he'll just scowl at me and then make the call for me. Or I'll dial the number and then hang up when I get a voice on the line.
output: This sounds like a real problem for you. And your fiancé sounds like he's not very patient with you.

instruction: Oh no. Luke is an absolute angel. I love him so much. He's the kindest, gentlest, sweetest man I've ever known, next to my daddy. He's just trying to get me out of the old habits that restrict me. I don't think he's a very good teacher though. He's the "dive right in" sort, and it takes me awhile to build up the steam for it. It takes a lot of energy to try something new. But Luke is always concerned about me and how I feel. That's why he called in to make an appointment for me. He's such a dear.
output: It sounds like you care for him very much.

instruction: He's the only man I've ever loved, next to Daddy.
output: You're close to your father?

instruction: Daddy is such a neat guy!  I wish he'd find someone, though. I can't stand to see him lonely. Right now my brother Isaac is staying with him, but Daddy needs a lady around.
output: And your mother?

instruction: Oh well, Mother remarried a couple years ago. She's happy. I'm glad for her.
output: You don't sound very glad.

instruction: There are a lot of things about Mother that I don't feel glad about.
output: How long have your parents been separated?

instruction: About ten years.
output: They separated when you were....

instruction: Ten.
output: Would you like to talk about that?

instruction: Sure, why the hell not? I'm going to be telling you every fucking thing else!
output: If this upsets you, we can talk about something else for now.

instruction: No, no, no. It's okay. I just really hate the way they split up. I'm extremely bitter about it.
output: That's to be expected.

instruction: I know. It's just that...well, why did she have to be such a bitch about it? She was so cruel to Daddy. She took everything that was important to him.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I don't know where to start. The beginning? Before they got married, Mom and Dad dated in high school. She was going to get a scholarship to an art school. Dad was a talented musician and actor and was well on his way to Juilliard. On their graduation night, Daddy proposed. Mom was the happiest woman on the planet. They were married two months later. Her parents were very wealthy.  They liked Daddy and they paid for the whole thing. They pulled favors, and spent a lot of money on the wedding. I have one of Mom and Dad's wedding pictures in my wallet. Here.
output: They look...

instruction: Uncomfortable, I know. Mom and Dad wanted a very small wedding. Her parents would hear nothing of it. Ultimately, Mom and Dad eloped before the wedding, and had their own personal ceremony. Then they pretended not to be married for the week before the wedding.  When they said their vows in front of all her parents' guests, they'd actually already been married a week.
output: That was rather brave of them.

instruction: Oh yes! It's rather romantic and dreamy. It wasn't going to last anyhow. A year later, they had Isaac--my grandparents named him. And nine months after Isaac, I was conceived. At first, Momma was happy that she could be a good mother and wife. But Daddy was unhappy. He had to refuse offers from Juilliard and other places so that he could get a real job and support his wife and children. But Dad made the sacrifice out of love. He never rubbed it in. He just approached it with love and maturity. And, like I said, Mom was happy at first. My earliest memory is of Mom and Dad sitting on the couch together and smiling. Everything was fine until I turned seven. Mom missed my birthday. She had an interview and completely forgot. Daddy made the cake and he and Isaac celebrated with me. I was crushed. Mom came home very late that night and I heard Daddy and Mother start to fight. I had never heard them argue before, so I scampered out of my bedroom. I pushed the door to their room open and saw Mother hitting Daddy. I screamed.
output: Hmm.

instruction: And then...and then...she grabbed my arm and led me back to my room. And she...she turned me over her knee and gave me a spanking. And she yelled at me and told me never to go in there again. I mean, how was I supposed to know? It was a new sound and it scared me. I never forgave her for that. I just remember crying, "Why Momma why?"
output: I can imagine that it was a traumatic experience.

instruction: Here I am thirteen years later, sobbing on a therapist's couch. How horrid.
output: There's no reason to be ashamed of childhood traumas having an effect in our adult lives.  That's how we're built as human beings.

instruction: Oh I know. It's just weird for me.
output: What happened after the spanking?

instruction: Well, it just got worse after that day. Momma kicked Daddy out of the bedroom and he started sleeping on the couch. She started spending more and more time away. Isaac and I were left to take care of each other. Then, when I was nine, Momma left for good. She just didn't come home one day.
output: What then?

instruction: It was so good! Daddy made sure we were taken care of, and he started going to night school. He always spent weekends with us, we did family things, and what with Mother not being around, we could laugh again. So much tension was dispersed. Isaac and I picked up the things Mother used to do and pretty well took care of each other. Until Mother came back.
output: Did your father ever instigate a search for your mother?

instruction: What, do you think he was a heartless bastard? Of course he did! No leads, nothing. She just disappeared. We all knew she was alive and well, but we did have a little farewell ceremony for her. We each took something that we felt represented her and drove out to the countryside. Daddy brought a little sketch that she had drawn for him. Isaac brought one of his old baby bottles. I brought a hat pin.
output: A hat pin?

instruction: She had this big floppy straw hat; she always wore her hair up. She would keep the hat secure on her head with this big old fashioned Victorian hat pin. It was about a foot long with this big faceted crystal bead on the non-pointy end. It also had little tassels around the bead; they were made of little strings of pretty garnet and amethyst beads. It was her great grandmother's. She was going to give it to me when I was old enough, but I knew deep down that there was no way she'd ever part with it willingly. So we each brought these things with us to the country. Daddy found this place: there was a willow tree with its branches dipping into the little river nearby. So Daddy placed all of our items into a box and dug a really deep hole. He placed the box in the hole and covered it up. Then he had each of us explain why we chose the items that we brought, and each of us said a little prayer for her. Daddy cried a lot that day.  Mother eventually did come back, but not for a year.
output: I think we covered a lot of important ground during this first session.  I would like to see you again and continue exploring these feelings if you'd like.

instruction: I think I would like that.
output: Well, then how about next week at this same time?

instruction: Certainly, I will be here. And thank you so much.
output: You are quite welcome. And Ms. Raven?

instruction: Yes?
output: It might be helpful if you would consider keeping a journal of your thoughts and feelings, or saving your doodles and sketches for me to look at. I don't need to read your journal if you don't want me too, but I would like to if you'd let me.  I've found a journal to be a valuable tool for my patients to try to clarify their feelings.

instruction: Well okay. I can try.
output: I'll see you next week then.  That's Tuesday, February 18th at noon.

instruction: That's fine.
output: Goodbye Eliza.

instruction: Good afternoon Dr. Balis. I hope you received my letter?
output: Yes I did.

instruction: Very good. Well, here is the list Luke provided me. I hope that you don't wish to stick to it, because I surely do not.
output: Let's see: "The Weather, Sports, Work, Music and your band, the News, Animals, and your Wedding Plans."  I don't know, I think I might like discussing the weather.

instruction: Good heavens Doctor! You're not serious!
output: No I'm not. Why don't we forget about Luke's list right now and just talk about what you want to talk about.

instruction: First off, let's not discuss my childhood right now. I find that it's rather boring and dreary. This is not just Luke's orders; it's my wish not to speak of it. I'd rather work backward, if that's okay with you.
output: That's fine. You mentioned that you are subject to crying spells in your letter.

instruction: Yes. I have them quite frequently. In fact, more frequently than I would like.
output: Is there anything in particular that triggers them?

instruction: It's usually something or other. Like the other day, I came home from work and started reflecting about my day. I remembered our session and it made me a little sad about my poor relationship with my mother. Well, Luke walks in from work. He asks me how my day was and I told him I was feeling a bit shaky about seeing you for the first time, but that it was nothing to worry about. He asked me what we talked about,and I told him nothing in particular. Well Luke knows me better than that and he started to grill me about it. Before I know it, I'm sobbing about having to talk about Mother and he goes off. He was ranting and raving and swearing and cursing. It was horrible. Before I knew it, he was hopping in his car and speeding off to your office to have a word with you. Apparently, you had already left for the day and so he came back home. He said his work with you was far from finished.
output: Hmm...

instruction: Well, that's how one of the episodes started. Others are brought on by nervousness, stress, anger. It's actually quite a release. It's my way of coping with the big bad world out there.
output: How often do you have these episodes?

instruction: The minimum is once a week. The maximum is twice a day.
output: When did you start having them?

instruction: About two years now. Not a day goes by when I'm not thinking whether I'm going to have another one.  I worry about how long it will last and whether I'll have enough kerchiefs for my nosebleeds.
output: Your crying sessions are accompanied by nosebleeds?

instruction: Almost always.
output: Tell me something. How do you feel about Luke?

instruction: I love him. With all of my heart and soul. It's like I'm in a fantasy land, and it's just me and him. He's chivalrous, beautiful, wonderful. Any woman would be glad to have him around. I'm a lucky woman.
output: Does Luke always stand up for you?

instruction: An example?
output: His phone call to me, for example.

instruction: Oh, I knew it! You are upset about that phone call! I begged him not to...I pleaded! I was on my hands and knees, for Christ's sake! He is extremely overprotective of me and anything that upsets me upsets him as well. He did it to vent his aggression, not to defend me! I wanted to talk about Mother, I swear! Oh please believe me!
output: Of course I believe you.  I'm sorry Eliza, I didn't mean to upset you. Here're the tissues.

instruction: I don't need them, thank you. I think I might want to go home now.
output: I don't think that would help you with your problems.

instruction: I don't know! I just can't make up my own mind!
output: Eliza...

instruction: Do you want me to stay? Well do you?!
output: Eliza, I...

instruction: Oh, you do not wish it! I knew it, I knew it, I knew it! Nobody wants me around, not even my own therapist!
output: Eliza!

instruction: Yes, good Doctor?
output: Please calm down. Let's work this through.

instruction: All right. I will stay then. But only because you want me to. Blast these nosebleeds!
output: It is my desire to help you work through your problems, not to make up your mind for you.

instruction: Then your're the only one who will let me make up my own mind.
output: Is that really true, Eliza?

instruction: Yes.
output: Who else makes your decisions?

instruction: Everyone! My Mother, Luke, his Mother, Isaac, Camille, Josie, Robin, Anders, my co-workers, my bosses, Luke's extended family, my extended family, Everyone I know makes up my mind for me!
output: I noticed that you didn't mention your father.

instruction: Even he does it sometimes! "Oh dear, you're not strong enough to make a decision on that." He can piss off, and so can the rest of them! They make me so angry! I hate them, I hate them, I hate them!
output: Have you ever tried to stand up for yourself?

instruction: Yes. A couple times. It didn't go over well.
output: What about Luke's father?

instruction: Dead. Car accident. Two years ago. He was driving home from one of my band's gigs and he was a little bit drunk. Head-on collision. I was lucky I was thrown from the car.
output: You were in that accident?

instruction: I do not want to talk about it.
output: Okay. Let's go back to what happened when you tried to stand up for yourself.

instruction: It happened so fast...
output: Pardon?

instruction: I am sorry, I was a bit distracted. I was saying that the accident happened so fast. The last thing I heard was him scream and then I was soaring and I skidded on my face...
output: Ow.

instruction: Yeah it did hurt. I remembered waking up in a hospital room and Luke standing over me, tears streaking down his face. I was so touched. I'd never seen him cry.
output: You were surprised to see him crying?

instruction: Well c'mon. Wouldn't you be surprised to see a former athlete crying his eyes out?
output: I guess I could be.

instruction: Well he was crying, saying over and over, "He's dead, dead Liz, dead. He's dead Liz. He's dead."
output: His father?

instruction: Yes. I was out for a week. His father died and so did the baby I was carrying.
output: You were pregnant?

instruction: It was really too soon for me to tell. My periods have always been at odd intervals, so two months without one was no big deal for me.
output: Does Luke know that you miscarried in the accident?

instruction: Yes. I talked with my doctor after I came out of my coma, and asked him what happened. He told me that I had miscarried in the accident. I felt it was my duty that Luke should know--he's so family oriented. I had to tell him; I couldn't get away with not telling him. It took me a week to work up the courage.
output: How did that talk go?

instruction: Not well at all. At first he laughed and said that it was a morbid attempt to try to cheer him up after his father had died. I kept insisting that there was no way I was lying and I got so emotionally worked up, that he finally believed me.
output: And?

instruction: All hell broke loose. He had a complete and total cow, if you don't mind me saying. Suddenly it was my fault that his father had died, and it was my intention to miscarry the baby. It was all my fault! All mine!
output: You weren't driving.  How could it have been your fault?

instruction: Oh, try telling that to Luke. Eventually, after the breakdowns started, he stopped and laid off me. He can't stand to see me cry or in pain in any way. So I guess that resolves that.
output: Are you taking medication for the accident?

instruction: Yes. I have to take painkillers for all sorts of things--Percocets. I was thrown face first. They had to do reconstructive surgery. They did a damned good job, no scars whatsoever. Well a few but, you know, not any noticeable ones. I broke both arms, a leg, and I got a concussion. I almost scraped all the flesh off my arms during that skid. After Luke told me that his father had died, I was in a coma for a week. I was in the hospital longer. Multiple fractions. Reconstructive surgery. Physical therapy. Pain, pain, pain. All the time. I couldn't write for awhile. Luke bought me a mini-cassette recorder for that. I put it in my lap top when I could type again. But it was a long time before I healed from that. And I have yet to begin healing emotionally. I have a recurring nightmare about it.
output: Tell me about that.

instruction: Well, in my dream I'm sitting in Gary's car--Gary was Luke's father--and I'm holding a baby in my lap. We're rolling along at a slow pace when suddenly I grab the wheel and swing one leg over the console and press the gas. We are careening toward another car, when I fling myself out the door, leaving Gary in the car. I take the baby with me. So I roll away. I look up in time to see the cars crash. And I start laughing hysterically. The baby starts to cry, and I begin to tear it apart, limb by limb. It's a little girl. Then I begin to walk away, still laughing. But then I turn around and Gary's pulling himself out of the wreckage. He starts to chase me, even though he's all mangled and everything. He's like a zombie, like "Thriller" and I start to scream. But then the baby pulls itself together and starts to toddle after me, zombie fashion. I turn around and run and run and run. They get closer. I feel Gary scrape the flesh on my arms. The baby manages to get my face. They corner me and close in, their rotting, putrid faces grinning and cackling. Then I wake up.
output: How often do you have this dream?

instruction: Oh about every two months. I wake up screaming.
output: What do you think the dream means?

instruction: I think it is me internalizing the guilt that I have about the wreck. They didn't know what the gender of the baby was, but I know, deep down inside somewhere, that it was a little girl. And I could have taken the keys from Gary but I didn't have the guts to. Besides, he had driven home tipsy before, so this time was really nothing different. I would have named her Callista Dominique.
output: Do mind if we discuss this some more in our next session?

instruction: We certainly can, Doctor Balis.
output: Okay. How about this same time next Tuesday.  That'll be the 25th of February at noon.

instruction: That sounds fine. I'll see you then.
output: Take care Eliza. Oh, and Eliza?

instruction: Yes?
output: Feel free to call me any time you need me, okay? I'm just a phone call away.

instruction: Very well then. I'm going to go commune with the trees now.
output: Goodbye Eliza.

instruction: Bye bye Dr. Balis. And thank you.
output: You're quite welcome.

instruction: Good afternoon, dear Doctor.
output: How are you today?

instruction: Luke? What are you doing here?
output: Ms. Raven?

instruction: I just wanted to apologize for my conduct on the phone the other day. I was terribly out of line.
output: You didn't have to do that, Mr. Howard.

instruction: Yes I did. I just have never had a girl that loves me as much as Lizzy here does, and I got carried away.
output: Apology accepted, Mr. Howard. Well um... Do either of you have anything special you want to talk about while you are both here?

instruction: Actually yes Dr. Balis. I need you to help me convince Lizzy to go to church.
output: Pardon?

instruction: I do not think. I know.
output: Hmm, Wicca.  Can you tell me some more about it?

instruction: As a Wiccan, or witch, I believe in a God and a Goddess. My religion is derived from the old world pagan religions. You know, like Mother Earth and Father Sky.
output: It sounds similar to Native American religious beliefs.

instruction: Dr. Balis, this is all a phase she's going through and she really needs help to get her out of it. I mean, once she goes too far, she'll never come back.
output: How do you think she's going too far?

instruction: She burns candles for everything! She's always mumbling or chanting something, and her meditation cuts into the time we could be spending together. If she wants to be spiritual, she could come to mass with me on Sunday, but she has to be so belligerent about it!
output: I don't think I understand...

instruction: What's there not to understand about it! She's practicing a mild form of Satanism right in my mother's home!
output: The two of you are living at your mother's home?

instruction: That's not fair Luke! That's not fair at all! Go home!  Go home! Go home! Go home!
output: Here.  Take this to staunch the blood.

instruction: Fine, I'm leaving. I'll talk to you later. Thank you, Dr. Balis. I hope you can sway her mind. I obviously can't.
output: Eliza?

instruction: Oh God. Oh God.
output: It's okay to take a few minutes.  Just put your head back like this and hold the tissue up.  There.  I think the bleedings almost stopped now.  I'm sorry about that Eliza.

instruction: No, no, no. It's not your fault. It's mine.
output: It's not your fault. Apparently he surprised you by coming today?

instruction: We talked about it once and I told him that I would be going alone. He told me that he was going to come with me to this session and I said no. We had a explosive argument, and when he calmed down, he said that he would let me go alone if that was my wish. I said it was. He must not have listened.
output: Is he abusive towards you, Eliza?

instruction: Like what do you mean?
output: "You shut your mouth right now."

instruction: He was angry.
output: That's true. Does he always talk to you like that when he's angry?

instruction: Only when he's mad.
output: How often does he get like that?

instruction: When I've been acting badly, he gets angry with me.
output: Do you think you were acting badly just now?

instruction: I don't know.  He thought I was.
output: Has he ever hit you?

instruction: No never. Never never never never.
output: Please don't cry again. We're just talking. Are you going to be all right?

instruction: I'll be fine...You're thinking I should leave him, aren't you?
output: Do you want to leave him?

instruction: Sometimes...I don't know. He's not always like that.
output: He seems like a very excitable person.

instruction: Yes. I guess that's the best way to describe him. His intentions are pure, but...oh. He can drive me crazy because he's so up and at 'em.
output: Hmm...

instruction: Well. He doesn't beat me and he is very kind. But it can be frustrating living with him because he's so conventional.
output: Hmm.

instruction: But you don't think I should leave?
output: It's not important what I think.  What you think is what's important.

instruction: I suppose it is.
output: I'm sorry Eliza, but we are out of time here.

instruction: Yes. I better go home and try to fix things there.
output: I'd like to see you next week if you can make it.

instruction: That would be fine.
output: Let's make it this same time on Tuesday, that's Tuesday, March 4th at noon, okay?

instruction: I'll see you then, Doctor Balis.
output: Eliza, if there is ever a problem, call me.  Day or night, my service can get a hold of me.

instruction: Thank you for your concern, Doctor. I'll call you if I'm in trouble.
output: Thank you Eliza.  I'm there if you need me.  Otherwise, I'll see you next week.

instruction: Fare thee well, Doctor.
output: Blessed be, Eliza.

instruction: You know about Wicca?
output: Just a little, Eliza.  Goodbye.

instruction: Afternoon, Doctor. Sorry I'm late.
output: Eliza? Is everything all right?

instruction: It's been a really draining week.
output: I'm sorry to hear that. Here, take a seat. You look exhausted.

instruction: I am. Last week, when I went home to apologize to Luke, he had calmed down a lot and we worked things out. He won't be dropping in for any more surprise visits. I'm glad.
output: But?

instruction: But he made me promise to go to church with him at least once.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I went Sunday and hated every bit of it.
output: Why is that?

instruction: By the end of Mass, everyone knew I was a "confirmed Satanist."  They were all trying to convert me back or burn me. The bad part was that Luke was egging them on. I have never been more humiliated. The priest even wanted to do an exorcism. I was mortified.
output: So much for interfaith toleration.  Did they harm you in any way?

instruction: Not physically, but the phone hasn't stopped ringing with people wanting to talk to "that poor girl at Mass on Sunday." It's taken everything in me to stand behind my beliefs. I've never explained Wicca to so many people before in my life. Luke has been apologizing daily for making me go, but I have yet to really say anything profound or meaningful to him. I spent Sunday night at Daddy's place and Luke called almost every half-hour to apologize. He's been sleeping on the couch every night since.
output: You decided on that sleeping arrangement?

instruction: Well, Monday night I locked him out of the bedroom. I guess I did. He told me he spent Sunday night on the couch too, because he couldn't face the bed alone.
output: Well, it sounds like you've had an interesting week.

instruction: Thank you, Doctor. I'm about to fall apart though. Oh, another terribly exciting thing that happened was that Daddy got engaged on Thursday. Isaac called Mother and told her. So Mother took me out for a nice little evening of shopping and grilling. She wanted to know all about Calypso, the lady Daddy is going to marry.
output: You never mentioned that your father was seeing anyone.

instruction: Calypso's been an on again, off again relationship. Daddy just realized that he loved her and finally proposed.
output: I see. Well it doesn't sound like you had a very fun evening with your mother.

instruction: Oh, hell no. First of all, she wanted me to buy this perfectly hideous pink chiffon thing, and then a pink Angora sweater, and then some pink patent leather Mary Janes. I mean...what? Is she trying to make up for lost time? Bitch.
output: Hmm.

instruction: Anyhow, then she starts asking me all these questions:  "What is this girl like? What does she do? Is she pretty? Do you like her?" which basically translates into "Is she more interesting than me? Does her job pay more than mine? Is she better looking than me?  Do you like her better than me?" Truth be told, Calypso kicks Mother's ass in general. She gorgeous, interesting, fun, smart, creative.  Everything that Daddy needs in a lady, Calypso's got. However, Mother was mortified to find out that she's black.
output: Oh?

instruction: Hilarious, isn't it? Well, these session are making me much stronger, Doctor, and I told her that if she wanted to know so much about my father's fiancée, here was her number and she could goddamned well call her herself!
output: Rather bold words.

instruction: Well, I got fucking sick of it. What business is it of hers? She left him in the cold and took everything important to him.  She doesn't want him, but no one else can have him either. Bitch. God, I hate her so much.
output: Do you mean that?

instruction: What? That I hate her?
output: Well, yes. Do you hate her?

instruction: I have a lot of anger in my system that belongs to her.
output: Well, there's a starting point for us. I would really like to get that out of your system.

instruction: Me too. I know I'm not supposed to hate my Mother, but whatever I feel sure feels similar to it.
output: I believe that it's okay to feel whatever you're going to feel.  The important thing is to figure out why you feel that way and to learn to live with the consequences of that feeling.  But that's something I'd like to save for next week. Can we move to another issue?

instruction: I'm game.
output: I've really been thinking about prescribing some medication for you that might help control the crying episodes you've experienced.

instruction: More drugs?
output: It's completely your decision, Eliza.  I'm not going to try to force you into it.  But I've seen many patients who find their emotions overwhelm them benefit from some form of anti-depressant.

instruction: I'm on so many drugs already. Take this in the morning, take this with lunch, take this with your afternoon snack, take this at dinner, take this before you go to bed, and make sure you take these once a day at the same time, and don't skip any! Shit. You want me on more drugs?
output: This is different from a Percocet.  It shouldn't make you feel drugged at all, just happier.

instruction: If you feel it'll help, let's try it. You know what I'm on. Anything that would make life nasty for me is a no-no. Otherwise, let's go for it. I doubt it could hurt anything further.
output: I'd like to have a conversation with your pain management specialist before I make my prescription.  I know you are taking Percocet, but you said there were other drugs?

instruction: Oh, it changes all the time.
output: He'll know what medications you're on.  I'll talk with him before our next session.

instruction: Sounds good. You know what?
output: What is that, Eliza?

instruction: I really look up to you. You're like what Daddy might have been if he went into psychiatry.
output: Well, thank you.

instruction: You're quite welcome.
output: I'd like to see you next week.  That's Tuesday, March 11th at noon. Is that okay?

instruction: That's fine. I'd better go now.
output: Okay, Eliza. I'll see you next week.

instruction: I'm sorry about being late. I'll be on time next week.
output: Thank you. Goodbye, Eliza.

instruction: Dr. Balis?
output: Eliza? Hello. You missed our appointment last week.

instruction: I know, I know. It was a terrible week. I was bogged down at work, there was a threat that I might lose my job, shit like that. But now I'm all caught up, so things are better.
output: Well, that's good. How is Luke?

instruction: I started talking to him again on Wednesday. He came to me and begged me to speak to him again, and he cried. I ignored him until he finished crying, and then I told him that next time he wouldn't get off so easily.
output: How was the rest of your week, aside from work and Luke?

instruction: I never got to tell you about this experience I had on the astral plane. It was amazing--the best I've had in a long time. Here, I wrote it down. Do you mind if I read it out loud?
output: Go right ahead.

instruction: Okay.  Purples, greens, setting sun. I am the Raven, circling the high skies and soaring on black wing. Below I spot the lone traveler. Upon closer inspection, after I spiral down out of the sky, it is a man, shimmering and beautiful. He looks at me with curiosity filling his shimmering eyes. Cock my head to one side, and hear his heart beating far away in a body that sleeps. He begins to speak, but a feather to his lips, soft and damp, silences him and I think to him: "Follow." Confused, he wants to speak again, but I spiral back up into the frothy clouds. He looks up and searches the sky for me. I fly above and go North. North is the direction for the earth. He starts to chase and I fly low to the ground. Maybe once he tries to catch me, but I jet ahead, mocking his movements. It is a running dance, forever to the North, that we partake in. He is running low on breath. I can sense that he has traveled too far from his dormant body. I spiral the ground, faster and faster, until my bird body catches fire. And as the spiral of fire dances, my form comes out of my ashes, and I have shape-shifted back into my humanoid form. He suddenly stops, as he has caught up, and he pants like a maddened lupine. His hands rest on his knees, and his body is doubled over. I cup his chin in my long hand and he looks into my eyes, instantly afraid and yet courageous. He wants me to stay. He tries to grab my hand and pull me back, but his hand passes through my ethereal body, and he calls out to me. It is too late, for I am once again in the atmosphere, reeling above. I call out once, in Raven's voice, and he waves my farewell. Then I awaken, knowing myself changed and yet the same.
output: Hmm.  Do you always write down your experiences?

instruction: Only the ones that seem to make a difference. You should have seen this guy! He was amazing. I wish I knew who he was.
output: Are you certain that this was an astral experience and not a dream?

instruction: Please, Dr. Balis. I know the difference. I sleep at night. This happened on my lunch hour. I meditate and sometimes go astral on my lunch hour. I'm very adept at what I do. Silly man.
output: I didn't mean to offend.

instruction: No offense taken, Doctor. I don't think that I will ever be able to find that guy again, but I'd like to try. He was beautiful. I'm just afraid Luke will find out about my mini-affair, and get upset with me. I don't need him mad at me again. Hey, guess what else?
output: What?

instruction: My crying spells have started to taper off a little. I have them maybe every other day now, on average, as opposed to every day.
output: I'm glad to hear that.

instruction: But I don't know how long they will be like that. I hope they go away completely.
output: Well, we can work on that. I spoke with your doctor, and he said that we could start you on the Zoloft.

instruction: I still don't know, Doctor. Did you speak with my gynecologist? I don't need anything that will interfere with my birth control. I know that you know, now, that it won't interfere with the Percocets, but what about my birth control? Here, this is what I'm taking.
output: Triphasil 28.  Okay, I'll take a look at it, and see what we can work out.  But I don't think there is going to be any drug interactions with your birth control pills.

instruction: Sounds like a plan, Doctor. Should we talk about Mother? I know you said something in our last session about wanting to talk more about her.
output: Yes.

instruction: Well, what exactly would you like to know?
output: Why do you feel anger regarding your mother?

instruction: Please, Doctor. I thought you were a little more observant than that. I've already told you what she did to me and my brother when we were little. And my Daddy. I can't think of a better reason to be angry with a person.
output: How did your father react to your mother leaving?

instruction: He denied it, at first. "She'll be back soon." He said that every day. I kept telling him that it wasn't so, but he was delusional. After he got over denying it, he pretended she was dead.
output: How did your brother take it?

instruction: He mourned for her. Nobody was angry but me.
output: How angry were you?

instruction: I only saw red when it came to my mother. I hated her for a long, long time. It's only recently come to the point where I can be in the same room with her without thinking about killing her.
output: And your brother and father mourned for her?

instruction: Yeah. The more angry I got, the more tearful they were.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I almost hated them for awhile, too. It was like they had never gotten over the initial shock of her leaving, and I had, and all I had left was anger, or maybe anger that they passed on to me.
output: So you think that you were feeling their anger for them?

instruction: Yeah, I guess you could put it that way.
output: Why did you take that on yourself?

instruction: Well, I guess I was the Mommy after she left. I was the caretaker. And Mother had done that with us. If someone had picked on us, she took care of that person. We never really got to work it out for ourselves. So I took on her role, I think. Does that make sense?
output: Yes, that makes sense, Eliza.

instruction: Do you think that I'm still carrying around their anger and mine?
output: Do you?

instruction: I don't want it!
output: Just relax.  Take a deep breath, and when you're ready, we can start again.

instruction: I'm sorry.
output: It's going to be okay. You have a lot of repressed anger and aggression, and that can be difficult to let out.

instruction: Why did I have to be the angry one?
output: Do you think you can answer that question?

instruction: Well, it wasn't going to be Isaac.  Oh, I hated Isaac sometimes, too. He and Daddy had this bond that I couldn't get inside. That's why they live together now. They're best friends and family. I never could have that.
output: Issac had your father as his role model.  Was your mother your role model?

instruction: I guess, I...I guess I wanted to be so much like her and fill her shoes.  I lost so much more than a mother when she left.
output: You wanted to emulate your mother and be as important to the family as she was, but she left her position in the household to you before you were ready.

instruction: Yeah. I was placed on a very lonely, very high pedestal.
output: Who placed you on that pedestal?

instruction: Daddy and Isaac. I never wanted...
output: You never wanted what?

instruction: Oh god.
output: Eliza?

instruction: Oh god. Oh god.
output: What is it, Eliza? What happened?

instruction: I wanted the pedestal. Because that's what Mommy was on for all of us. I wanted it. Oh god.
output: She was your role model.  It's understandable that you wanted what she had.

instruction: I never knew. I never knew how much I wanted that lonely position.
output: Is it that it's lonely?  Did you ever let them know how lonely you felt?

instruction: Never. I held it in and just felt resentment. Oh sure, part of me enjoyed the hell out of being a princess, but the real side of me--the human side--wanted the affection and attention due to a scared little girl.
output: Do you think they thought of you as a scared little girl?

instruction: No.  They didn't know that part.
output: Well, how could they have known that you needed to be treated like one?

instruction: They couldn't.
output: So do you think you should be angry with them?  If they didn't know what you needed and you never told them, then it wasn't really their fault.  Why weren't you honest with them about how you felt?

instruction: How the hell was I supposed to do that? I was a little girl, for Christ's sake! Just a little girl. And all I knew was that I had to keep it quiet that my Mommy was gone and I was the new mommy. How can a little girl tell someone that she needs some more support? How does a little girl that is trying to be the mommy say, "Hey, I'm scared and I don't know how to do this." How should I have done that? Well?
output: You were too young to be thrust into that role.  But it may be that you have misplaced your feelings of anger.  Can you explain your anger towards your brother and father?

instruction: I can't! It's not rational! And I'm not the bad guy here, she is! She's the one who left and left me all alone!
output: I'm sorry, Eliza. I'm sorry to have made you cry.

instruction: Liar.
output: I had to push the limits.

instruction: No, you didn't.
output: What would have happened if I hadn't?

instruction: I don't know.
output: Tell me what you think would have happened.

instruction: We would have never known the truth?
output: I have to push you, Eliza.  I know this session was emotionally draining.  But I think we got a lot accomplished.  Do you think it was productive?

instruction: Actually, it was.
output: Good, Eliza.  I'd like to schedule you for another session.  Is this time next week okay with you?

instruction: Tuesday at noon?
output: Yes.

instruction: I'd like that. But please, don't make me cry again.
output: Well, there are no promises, Eliza. We are going to be exploring painful subjects.  But there's nothing wrong if you express your emotions during our sessions.

instruction: Well, I have to go. Farewell, good Doctor.
output: Goodbye, Eliza.

instruction: Afternoon, dear Doctor.
output: Hello, Eliza.

instruction: Sorry I missed last week.
output: Well, I was very worried about you.

instruction: Things were hectic again.
output: Well, perhaps we should slow your sessions down if you can't make it in but once every other week.

instruction: Dr. Balis!
output: I'm sorry, Eliza. I had the flu last week and am still feeling a bit under the weather.

instruction: Well, you don't have to take it out on me.
output: I really am sorry.

instruction: So am I. I wish I could have made it in. Things have really slowed down at work and on the home front, so it should be easier to get to my sessions. Can you forgive me, please?
output: Well...

instruction: Oh, good Doctor! I didn't mean to be like this!
output: I'm pulling your leg, Eliza. Yes, you're forgiven. I would just like your treatment to be a little more consistent. It's like exercising. If you want to get in shape, you have to be on a consistent schedule.

instruction: And if I want my emotions and such in shape, my sessions need to be consistent. I get it.
output: Good. Where would you like to begin today?

instruction: Well, last time, we talked about Mom.
output: You're calling her "Mom" now?

instruction: I think part of me had to forgive her. I can't call her "Mother" anymore. I used that word like an insult. On the other hand there's Father...
output: Are you angry with your father now?

instruction: He's not quite the prince I thought he was.
output: What happened to change your mind?

instruction: He's making wedding plans, right? Well, Calypso is being absolutely cool. She wants me in the wedding, along with Isaac. In fact, she's made an effort to meet Mom and have a talk with her about Father. Mom went one step further and gave Calypso a locket she used to carry around with her when she was AWOL from the family. It has Isaac's and my pictures in it. But Father had a fit and said that Calypso can't have it and she definitely can't wear it. I don't know why he reacted like that.
output: Well, it is a locket his ex-wife used to have.

instruction: He idolized Mom. He worshipped the ground she walked on. I don't know what happened.
output: Well, what has changed in the past few weeks?

instruction: Family-wise?
output: Yes.

instruction: Well, let's see.  Isaac and his new girlfriend are already having problems. Father and Calypso are making wedding plans. Isaac and I are doing the same. Father has been distancing himself from me. Calypso is trying to be my new best friend. Mom and I have started to talk about the past. Um, Father and Isaac have been fighting a lot lately. Isaac and Calypso are forming a weird alliance. Isaac refuses to talk to Mom. I don't know what else to tell you. Mom and Calypso are making some tenuous moves toward being kind to each other.
output: Wait a second.  That's quite a list.  You said that you and your mother are talking about the past?

instruction: I finally told her I was going to therapy. She surprised me and said she'd been going for about a year now. All of a sudden, she has a human side. So, I asked her what she went in for. Mom is in therapy to sort out her problems. So, we talked about therapy. And she wanted to know what you and I talk about. I thought to myself, What the hell. Our relationship can't get any worse. I told her, "A lot of stuff, and you," "Me?" she said. "You." I said. Then she wanted to know what about her. And there we were, talking about my therapy sessions and her. I finally got up the courage to ask her why she left. She managed to show me, in some sort of way, that her leaving wasn't out of pure malice. So now, Mom and I have started over, and very slowly are working to a point where we can restore our relationship. It's like I'm reading a book which started out poorly, but is suddenly getting better, and I like it.
output: Hmm...maybe your father is reacting to you and your mother's newfound relationship.

instruction: Maybe, but I don't think that's all that's going on.
output: What do you mean?

instruction: I could see him reacting by distancing himself from me. But I don't know why he is always fighting with everyone around him.
output: Is this something new from your father?

instruction: He's always been the sweetest...Doctor, I'm really worried about this. I don't want to completely lose my father, but it feels like that's what's happening.
output: Perhaps your father is going through some problems that he needs to work out right now.  Preparing for a marriage is often a time for introspection.

instruction: I don't know, but I miss him.
output: It's unfortunate that just when you're forging a relationship with your mother that you are experiencing a distancing from your father.

instruction: But I need to understand where Father is coming from.
output: I believe you'll have to talk to your father for the answers. I'd like to change the subject if I may.

instruction: Okay.
output: Have you thought about the medication?

instruction: Well, you already said it was okay.
output: I've checked with your other doctors and everything seems like it will work out well.

instruction: But...
output: But I do need to counsel you a little on your smoking.

instruction: My...my smoking?
output: Look, Eliza, smoking is always bad for you.  I know that you know that and I'm not going to give you a general lecture about the dangers of smoking.  I'm sure you've heard it before.  But with regard to the birth control medication you're taking, there's a substantially increased risk of some nasty side effects if you smoke.

instruction: Oh, Doctor. You are a silly man.
output: I feel that I am justified in my concern, Eliza.

instruction: I figured because you were a Doctor, you'd realize why I choose those birth control pills.
output: Oh?

instruction: I got the ones that were the least likely to cause me harm when I smoke. And I've really cut back on the smoking. I'm down to a pack a day. For me, that's an excellent feat.
output: Well, I guess you have had this lecture before.

instruction: Several times, Doctor. I do know that one day, I'd like to quit. Perhaps now is not the time, but it is a goal in the future.
output: It is wise of you to set goals for yourself.

instruction: Thank you, Doctor. I thought so too.
output: Well, Eliza, is there anything else on your mind that you need to talk about? Perhaps we can talk about your relationship with Luke.

instruction: Well, Luke and I are fine. Things at home are kind of boring, if you don't mind me saying.
output: Not at all. It does seem that our time here is up, though.

instruction: Oh.
output: Here's a prescription for Zoloft.  I have a patient information sheet that I'd like you to read.  And I want you to call me, night or day, if you notice anything strange with this medication.  It will take a couple of weeks for us to really be able to evaluate its effect, but I think it could really make a lot of difference in your mood.

instruction: All right.  How do I take this stuff?
output: I'm sorry.  It's a pill that you'll take once each morning.

instruction: That's it?  Just one pill a day?
output: That's it.  We'll see how you're doing on it over the next four weeks or so. Can I schedule you for an appointment for next week?

instruction: Yes.
output: Will you show up?

instruction: That was uncalled for, Doctor.
output: I'm sorry, Eliza. I thought I was being humorous.

instruction: Not quite.
output: Okay, I have you scheduled for Tuesday of next week.  That's April 15th at noon, okay?

instruction: Sounds great.
output: I'll see you then, Eliza.

instruction: Okay, Doctor. See you then.
output: Goodbye, Eliza.

instruction: D...Dr. Balis?
output: Eliza...oh!

instruction: Oh, it's so horrible!
output: Eliza, please...oh...please sit in your chair.  We can't have a session with you sitting on my lap the entire time.

instruction: It's awful!
output: Please try to stop crying, and tell me what it is.  Oh, dear...

instruction: Oh, I'm sorry.  I hate when that happens.  I guess it's bad if other patients see you with blood all over your clothes.  Do you have another shirt?
output: It's okay, here's a tissue. I've got a stain stick.

instruction: It's not fair!
output: Why don't you try to tell me what's wrong.

instruction: I'm sorry, Dr. Balis. I've just had this need lately...
output: That's okay, Eliza. Tell me what's going on.

instruction: It's so horrible.
output: Hmm.  Here's some Kleenex. We'll start when you catch your breath.

instruction: I told Luke about my experience.  You know, the one I told you about?
output: The astral plane experience?

instruction: The same.
output: I gather he didn't take it well?

instruction: He got so mad. He accused me of cheating, packed up my things, and kicked me out.
output: He kicked you out? Where are you staying?

instruction: I couldn't stay at Dad's, so I went to Mom's place.
output: So why did you decide to tell Luke about that experience?

instruction: Well, Thursday night we went out for dinner. He started researching the astral plane and was really making an effort to understand my beliefs. So we were talking about it, and it was really great. And he asked me about some of my experiences. So I told him a few.  And then--I couldn't help it, that time was just so amazing for me--it slipped out.
output: And what happened?

instruction: Nothing really. He was very calm about it.  I thought it had been a good thing to tell him, you know?  We were getting really close.  We went to a movie afterwards. But when we got home, he asked me more probing questions about that time on the astral plane. Questions like: "Do you want to see him again?" and  "Do you find him attractive?" Somehow he read into my answers an admission of guilt of sleeping with someone on the astral plane! He said he read about people who have done that before.  And he said that that's probably why I have a higher sex drive than him. I'm a nympho.  And when I couldn't get what I needed from him, I went and fucked on the astral plane!
output: Hmm.

instruction: I told him that was absolutely absurd! Then he said that if I thought that I needed to defend myself, then I was guilty. So he packed most of my things up for me and placed them by the door. He said he might call me, but not to count on it. It's not fair!
output: I'm sorry, Eliza.

instruction: Me too.
output: Why couldn't you stay at your father's?

instruction: That's all screwed up too. After our session last week, I rushed home, determined to talk to him. I barged right in during the middle of an argument between him and Calypso. He was breaking off their engagement right then and there. He said that we're all crowding him and he needed space, and why can't we all just leave him alone! So Calypso left in tears.  And Isaac followed. So now Isaac is staying at Calypso's. They all kind of made up.  And Dad is going to go to a therapist to resolve some issues.
output: What kind of issues?

instruction: His unresolved feelings of unrequited love for my mother.
output: Hmm.

instruction: Yeah, my family knows how to put the "fun" in "dysfunctional."
output: Hmm.  So, how is staying at your mother's working out?

instruction: Good, actually. She's given me a lot of time to cry and has called in sick for me at work--I just don't feel ready to go in yet. Anyhow, she and Ben--her husband--have been very kind. I always just thought that Ben was just a conservative Republican type, but he actually has a sense of humor and is very nice. He also makes great Belgian waffles and a mean ice cream sundae.
output: It sounds like you think he's a nice guy.

instruction: He is. I just can't believe that Luke and I are through.
output: It's normal to be sad at the end of a relationship.

instruction: I know.  But the truth is I don't know if it's over. He said he might call.
output: But he might not.

instruction: I hope he does. I miss him so entirely. I even miss the pimples on his back.
output: I'm sorry, Eliza.

instruction: I just don't know what to do! I want him back. Should I call him? Should I wait for him to call me? Should I parade past his office with a new guy on my arm every hour? Should I crawl to his front door and scratch at it pathetically, whining? And when he answers it, should I throw my arms around his ankles and hold on for dear life like a Chihuahua?
output: What do you want to do?

instruction: I want to cry and mope!
output: Expressing your emotions is healthy, but ultimately crying and moping is not a solution.

instruction: I know. I just...I just want him back so badly.
output: Then you're going to have to do something about it. It probably won't be today or tomorrow.  But somewhere down the road, you're going to have to figure out what you need to do to get Luke back--if that's truly what you want. I'd really like to start working on that.

instruction: Okay. Dr. Balis, I'm really feeling weak and very vulnerable. I wish I knew what's going to happen.
output: It's okay, Eliza. You're allowed to feel that way. And you're probably going to feel that way for a while. I know that you can make it through this. You just need to be strong. But know that it's okay to feel whatever you are going to feel.

instruction: Can we cut the session here, please? I feel like I need to go home and rest a little, please?
output: Sure. We're almost out of time, anyway. Can I get you in here next week?

instruction: Oh, yes. I know things are far from resolved.
output: Okay, how does April the 22nd at noon sound?

instruction: That's good.  Yes. Thank you, Dr. Balis.  I really needed you.
output: I'm surprised that you didn't call.

instruction: I didn't want to bother you.  And I spent most of the past few days just sobbing.  I needed to be held, but Dad was busy being alone. And Luke...well, you know all about that.
output: I hope you feel better, at least a little.

instruction: Oh, I hope so too. I'll be seeing you.
output: Okay, Eliza. Don't forget, call me if you need me. Anytime.

instruction: Okay. Fare thee well.
output: Goodbye, Eliza.

instruction: Oh, Doctor Balis?
output: Yes, Eliza?

instruction: I almost forgot. There's one small piece of sunshine in my life. My band, The Dozin' Pozers, is playing a gig on the 25th. I got you a ticket and a backstage pass, if you'd like to go.
output: I'll have to see. But I'd like to see you perform.

instruction: Well, here you go. Call me if you need more tickets.
output: I'll do that.

instruction: Bye now.
output: Goodbye.

instruction: Good afternoon, Doctor Balis.
output: Good afternoon, Eliza. You look chipper.

instruction: I am.
output: Oh? Something new happening?

instruction: Something old re-happening. Check this out.
output: That's a very pretty ring, Eliza.

instruction: Luke's apology.
output: Am I right in assuming that the two of you are back together?

instruction: Correct as always.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I accepted his three carat apology. Graciously, I might add.
output: So, he presented you with a ring as his apology, and you accepted it, with no arguments or deliberations?

instruction: I'm not about to fall into an old trap. We had it out, if that's what you are probing for.
output: I was.

instruction: Hmm. Anyhow, Luke came crawling over to my mother's home Friday night, and pleaded his way into the house. Ben wasn't going to let him in until I, in my stupidity and loneliness, demanded that Ben let him in. We went into the living room, and Luke proposed again. At first I told him no. He begged and pleaded and apologized--just weaseled his way into my heart--and I melted. So, I took him back, on one condition.
output: And that was...?

instruction: One mistake--anything that hurts me in a deep way--and we're history for good. Not petty things like astral projection or disagreements, but things like cheating, kicking one another out, that sort of thing.
output: Are you happy with how things worked out?

instruction: Things are coming into place like I want them to. I even got up the nerve to call a creditor back and tell them where to go.
output: Oh?

instruction: Car loan. Assholes are calling me every two hours, even when I'm at work, making more money to pay them their goddamned payment. I said that if they needed to get a hold of me, why didn't they call me in the evening when I would be home, rather than during the day, when I'm not?  They call and leave dirty nasty-grams on my answering machine. They tried to get snotty and I told them that the check will be on its merry little way shortly.
output: How are things going with your mother?

instruction: Swell. I got up the nerve to tell her I hate pink.
output: I'm sorry?

instruction: I like bold, rich colors, and I can't stand pastels. Mom's a Spring, if you look up color charts and things, and I'm a Winter. So, I don't look very good in pastels. I tried on something pink to show her, and she cringed. She finally came to terms with the fact that, no matter what, she can't shove a nipple in my mouth and make up for lost time. So we getting to know each other. It's quite weird.
output: How so?

instruction: Well, we never knew each other very well. Now it's more like we are equals, rather than the old Mother-Daughter bullshit. And I think I like this arrangement better.
output: Why?

instruction: Daddy is my father and my mother. I know that sounds strange.
output: No, it doesn't.

instruction: I just can't let Mom take his place as one of the people who raised me. I never grew up when I was around her. Daddy raised me. She was gone. She wasn't there for films and talks about female sexuality. She wasn't there for the heartaches and breakups. She wasn't there at my Sweet Sixteen birthday party. Well, she was there monetarily. But money doesn't make a mother. So Daddy took over for her. Mom wasn't there through my agonizing physical rehabilitation. Daddy was. Do you see what I mean?
output: I do.

instruction: So I've been thinking about all of this and Mom and I sat down the other night to talk. And I told her what was on my mind. She said she didn't blame me and that she was ashamed of the way she acted when she left. I couldn't believe it. It blew my mind. Mom sat down and cried. She feels guilty for missing our lives. She said, "I know you don't understand why I did what I did. But I did the right thing for me. My only regret is missing out on you and Isaac. I'm not apologizing and I don't expect you to forgive me. All I know is that I may have given birth to you, but your father created you and turned you into an angel." So I held her while she cried, smoothed her hair, and shushed her.
output: Are you embarrassed?

instruction: Well...well, yeah. I was mommying my mother. I was doing what I did for Isaac and Daddy all those years. But this time, it didn't hurt deep inside to do it.
output: Why do you think it didn't hurt?

instruction: Well, first of all, I was too young to handle the responsibility with Daddy and Isaac. And secondly, Mom is more like a friend than a mother. She was just a friend who needed comforting.
output: So you and your mother are friends now?

instruction: Well, yes and no. We are each trying to learn about the other rather than talking about who we were before. We are starting fresh. So it's like we just met and are still in the getting-to-know-you stage.
output: How is your father handling all of this?

instruction: He took all of her things and gave them back.
output: Could you please explain? I think I am a bit confused.

instruction: At the suggestion of his therapist, a Doctor Humdingerschlossenberg or some other such rubbish, he took all of Mom's things that he had stored away--her pictures, art, clothes, everything, even the pillow she slept on and the sheets they got at the wedding--and took it back to her. He held a rummage sale to get rid of their old furniture. It was an act of sheer bravery. He drove over to Mom's with a U-Haul, and knocked bravely on her door. Ben answered it. Now, you have to realize, Ben stands almost a full foot over Dad. But Dad stuck out his chest and asked if my mother was home. Ben snarled, "Who wants to know?" Daddy retorts: "I do, you ogre." By then, Mom was at the door. "What can I help you with?" she asks Daddy. "The things that you left are here in the truck. If you want them, you need to unload them, and if you don't, I'll take them to the dumpster and get rid of them for you." Well, Mom didn't know what she had left, so they unpacked the truck, all three of them together. And as they were parting, he said, "I'm going to sell the furniture on Saturday. If you want anything, come and get it. If not, I'll still give you half of the proceeds." Mom answers, "You never had a head for antiques. I'll pick those up and give you half of whatever we make on them." They shook on it and Daddy left. Then he went home and sat on the couch and cried for an hour.
output: He really still cares for your mother.

instruction: That, and he cried because he couldn't do what Dr. Pinderschloss wanted him to do.
output: And that was...?

instruction: Cut Mom out of all of the family photos. He was supposed to cut her image out and leave a picture with me, Isaac, Daddy, and a hole. It was a horrid, tacky idea and I told Daddy that I thought it would be okay to leave them intact. I asked Daddy who was this awful doctor he was seeing? It did brighten Daddy's day, a little.
output: And Calypso?

instruction: I was just getting to that. They made up this week and Isaac moved back in with Daddy. Daddy and Calypso are going to therapy together. Calypso agrees that Dr. Whatizbutt is a loony. It was like national "Kiss and Make-Up" week for my family.
output: Hmm. Tell me about your band.  The performance is Friday and I'm looking forward to it.

instruction: I'm glad you're going to come.  My band is myself, Camille--my best friend, Anders--a drag queen, Robin and Josie--a gay couple.
output: Okay. Is there anything else I should know?

instruction: Well, Camille is pregnant. She thinks that the baby's father is Malcolm, her ex-boyfriend. She invited him to the gig so that she could tell him. I think she is looking for a fight.
output: Does this worry you?

instruction: Malcolm the Malcontent. Yes. He worries me.
output: Malcolm the Malcontent?  Who calls him that?

instruction: Oh, I don't know.  That's just the name he has, but maybe not to his face.  He's the weirdest--incredibly tall and thin, brooding and dark. He scares me, but I am the only person he confides in. I'm the only one who knows why he moved here. I haven't seen him much in the last month or so, since he and Cami broke up, but I know that he's going to come to the show. He likes the music. Camille gave him three tickets, so he's probably bringing Gary and Simon.
output: Is Camille trying to get him back?

instruction: She's trying.
output: I see.

instruction: Cami's just...well, she's a little promiscuous. She likes to play cat and mouse games with the men in her life. She likes to string them along. Malcolm won't play, or if he does play, he doesn't play according to Camille's rules. She likes sex. She likes kinky, wild, uninhibited sex. She walks a tightrope all the time, and she doesn't protect herself. And it scares me, more than Malcolm and his unhappy tendencies. Sometimes I feel that there's something horrible, lurking just on the edge, waiting to spring out and trap her.
output: Have you ever told her how you feel?

instruction: You can't tell Cami what scares you. She'll do it more just to drive you insane. So I don't tell her. I just "tsk tsk" like a mother hen, and pretend to agree with what she's doing. You don't disagree with Camille. She will make life hell for you.
output: Hmm.

instruction: Anders on the other hand...
output: Yes?

instruction: Anders is a trip. Anders--Alexandria the Great on stage--is a Cleopatra drag queen. He talks like Noxema but acts like Vida, you know from the movie "To Wong Foo". Now, he really is the complete mother hen, clucking and preening, and so on. His husband Phillip is your typical little man. Like in the cartoons, there is a very large woman that controls everything and this little man, and all he says is "Yes, dear." Phillip is an accountant. Phillip is completely unlike Anders, he's very tame.
output: It sounds like you look up to Anders.

instruction: Not look up to, per se. More like I am amused by him. I love his attitude.
output: I look forward to meeting your group. It sounds like an interesting collection of people. Well, it looks like we are out of time here.

instruction: Well, shall we meet next week?
output: Yes, noon on Tuesday, the 29th?

instruction: Same bat time, same bat channel.
output: Sure. See you next week, Eliza.

instruction: Dr. Balis?
output: Yes? Oh come in, Eliza. You don't have to wait for me to invite you in.

instruction: I know. I guess I just...oh never mind. It's been hell.
output: I saw your performance Friday.

instruction: And I assume you got to see the Grande Finale as well.
output: Well, I didn't get to see it first hand. I waited around after your performance, saw a crowd gathering, and heard loud, angry voices getting louder and angrier by the second, so I took it as a sign to depart.

instruction: That was just Malcolm and Camille going at it.  They got kind of physical.
output: Was anybody hurt?

instruction: Malcolm knocked the wind out of her by dropping her to the ground with his karate. Of course, this was after she nailed him in the 'nads. The only other injury was my smarting cheek after she slapped it.
output: What did Camille do that for?

instruction: I got into the middle of the argument. No one opposes the great and mighty Camille. Anyhow, I'm not her best friend anymore.
output: Because she slapped you?

instruction: Because she and Luke were involved in a...tryst. So to speak.
output: I beg your pardon?

instruction: Oh, I can't talk right. Just...here. Look at these photos.
output: These give the phrase "compromising positions" a new twist...

instruction: Stunning, aren't they. I thought so, too.  You wouldn't think anyone would get pierced there, would you?
output: How did you get pictures this explicit?

instruction: They were asleep.  I just took them and they never woke up.
output: This is really surprising, Eliza. You were really torn up when Luke last broke your engagement. Now, although you've clearly caught Luke with his pants down, so to speak, you don't even show a hint of emotion.

instruction: It's nothing to get emotional over. He can't control me that way anymore.
output: I don't think that this is a control issue.

instruction: Well, I don't want to get emotional. I don't want to get bloody. I don't want to have a sob-fest. I'm tired of all of that shit.  And I'm tired of his shit.
output: Are you staying at your mother's again?

instruction: Oh, hell no. I haven't even shown these to Luke and Camille yet. I don't want to break up the band now that we have just gotten on our feet again. And I really want Luke to confess his infidelity to me before I whip these babies out for him.
output: Well...

instruction: I know. I know, I know, I know. I've been exhausted since Friday night. That performance really drained me. And then I ran into Peter. Well, that was interesting, to say the least. And then I get home to find these two wrapped up in a lover's embrace in his mother's bed. His mother's fucking bed! Goddamn him!
output: So there is some emotion.  But I thought you said...

instruction: I don't want to be sad about it. But I have every right to be angry and hurt. I trusted that bastard with my goddamned soul and he tears that trust to shreds and stomps on it by sleeping with Camille! With Camille! Camille the Chameleon! Camille, the slut from downtown! Why couldn't it have been some gorgeous super model? Why did it have to be the underage whore?
output: It's okay to be angry and hurt, Eliza. You shouldn't have held it back.

instruction: If I hadn't exploded just then, I would have done it when I walked in the room. And then I would have felt bad for yelling at you. It's easier to let it leak out rather than scare the hell out of you.
output: That's all right, Eliza. I wouldn't have taken it personally. I understand something about people under emotional distress.

instruction: I figured as much. Actually, I'm not mad. I'm disgusted.
output: Why?

instruction: Duh. Hello? Camille is a skanky little ho. And Luke, the very same who begged forgiveness from me, slept with her. And they were taking photos with his mother's goddamned Polaroid. So when I found them after I got home--they were naked and asleep--I couldn't help myself. I grabbed a new thing of film, slammed it into the camera, and started snapping away. I left the pictures that they had taken together. I wanted them to have those snap shots. But these...these are mine. These are for keeps. These are to remind me what a sorry piece of shit I really am.
output: Eliza, I'm lost. You're a "sorry piece of shit" because Luke cheated on you?

instruction: No, not because he cheated on me. Because I let him into me. I let him into my heart and soul. I let him hurt me. I let him in.  Nobody else let him hurt me. I did. It's my own goddamned fault.
output: So who are you angry at? Him? Or you? Or Camille?

instruction: All of the above.
output: Everybody makes choices, Eliza.  Luke chose to sleep with Camille--that choice affected you.  Camille chose to sleep with Luke--that choice affected you too.  You can be affected by someone else's choices without being responsible for them. You did not make those decisions.

instruction: Well, I could have been there for Luke to sleep with.
output: Luke made his own decision.  He decided that sleeping with Camille was more important than staying faithful to you.

instruction: No...
output: Luke made the choice. He could have kept his hands to himself.

instruction: But...
output: But he didn't. That decision affected you, but it wasn't caused by you.
You can't blame yourself for his choices and decisions. You can't be responsible for everyone, Eliza. You're only responsible for your own choices, just as Luke is responsible for his.

instruction: Damn it! I am! I am responsible for me!
output: Then why do you have to be responsible for him?

instruction: I fucking don't!
output: That's right.

instruction: Oh shit.
output: Sit down, Eliza. You look like you're about to faint.

instruction: I'm not going to...
output: Eliza?

instruction: Yeah?
output: Put your head between your knees.

instruction: It's all right. This, too, shall pass. Thanks for bringing me back down.
output: I'm sorry?

instruction: I do like it when you get aggressive. We get so much more accomplished. When you get frustrated with me, you really come on strong. I have to be pried open. Trapping me in a corner is most effective.
output: I don't get frustrated with you. I'm sorry, Eliza, if I came on too strong.

instruction: Don't be. Thank you for your efforts. I never feel so free as when I'm here.
output: I think I'll take that as a compliment.

instruction: It was intended as one.
output: Well...

instruction: What shall we do about Luke the Puke?
output: Luke the Puke?

instruction: Luke the Puke.
output: Okay, Luke the Puke.

instruction: Yes. What shall we do about him?
output: That's up to you. What do you want to do?

instruction: I really want him to come to me and confess. And if he doesn't confess, I'll go to Confession for him.
output: Pardon?

instruction: I was thinking of passing these pics around his church.
output: I don't think that would be such a grand idea, Eliza.

instruction: I know. I've had too much time to think since early Saturday. I was feeling vindictive and angry.
output: That's understandable.

instruction: Actually, I don't want to be immature about it. I don't want to cry and mope now. I just want to end this torture.
output: Torture?

instruction: I know that he's cheated on me. By sleeping with my former best friend, no less. I don't know if it's weighing on his mind like it is on mine. I almost see it as a fitting punishment.
output: That he is being tortured by his conscience?

instruction: Exactly.
output: Well, how you handle it is ultimately up to you. I believe that you will make the right decision.

instruction: The only thing I ever learned: do the right thing.
output: Okay. So go and do the right thing, Eliza. I have faith that you will.

instruction: Anyhow. It was really good to get this off my chest. I thought I was going to explode.
output: No one else knows about this?

instruction: I haven't told anybody. If Luke or Camille did, that's up to them. Kiss and tell. That's not Luke's style, but it is Camille's. He may have sworn her to secrecy, but I doubt it. I'm pretty sure I'll be hearing about it through the grapevine pretty soon.
output: Well, rumors wouldn't be the best way to confront them. They can deny everything. But you have the proof in your hands.

instruction: I'm not going to use it...just yet. I'll save it for when I decide how to handle the situation.
output: Sometimes you just have to step back from a situation and see it in another light.

instruction: I know. Anyhow. Enough about those dumb asses. Let's talk about Peter.
output: Peter?

instruction: Peter Hossfeld. I met him Friday night, after the show. He'd been giving me weird looks all night, and I knew there was something about him that I couldn't place. So I ran out and grabbed him before he could leave with the stampeding herd. It was very surreal when I caught up with him.
output: How so?

instruction: I looked into his eyes, and I just knew...I just knew. There was something there. It was amazing.
output: Wait a minute. What exactly did you know?

instruction: Well, at first, nothing. I made him promise not to leave until I had a chance to talk to him, and rushed backstage to find out why there was a growing throng on the outskirts there. Which is where I found Camille and Malcolm screaming at each other. Well, I got out of there after the police left...
output: The police were involved?

instruction: Luke got panicky and called in some bacon to help out with what he thought was going to end in Camille's death. Part of me wishes it had. But anyway, I got back to Peter after the police left, and he got upset when he saw that mark on my face. I told him it was nothing and that he didn't need to worry. He calmed down. Well, my gut instinct was to get him alone and sit down and talk with him.
output: Weren't you afraid?

instruction: I don't know why, but I wasn't. I just felt this need growing inside me, like I was on the edge of a cliff. A little voice ran through my mind, "You have to talk to him. You have to talk to him. You have to talk to him." So I invited him out for coffee. He sneered at the word coffee, but he did say that he wanted to talk to me.
output: And then what happened?

instruction: Luke showed up.
output: Uh oh.

instruction: No. He just demanded, "Who's this?" I didn't know his name at the time, but he stepped in and introduced himself as an acquaintance of mine. So then I told Luke that we were going out for coffee and asked if he'd like to join us? "Oh, no," Luke said, "You run along with your little friend." So he let us go.
output: Did you intend to invite him along?

instruction: No, but I was going to tell him what was up. Anyhow, I wasn't going to get in trouble over this, so I toddled after Luke and asked him in private if it was really okay for me to go. He said that it was, and that he was planning on going with Anders and everyone out for drinks. He said that we were welcome to join them if we wanted to. I said, "No, he's a spiritual-type friend. We don't want to muddle our thinking." So Luke sent me along and kissed me good night, telling me that he would see me when I got home.
output: Hmm.

instruction: Peter and I left. We went to a little shop open 24 hours in my neighborhood. I drank a lot of coffee and he drank something weird--I think it was "Wheat Germ Water" or something nasty like that. Anyhow, I think he may have been the guy in the experience I had.
output: Wait a minute...the astral plane experience?

instruction: Yes. But the weird thing was that he kept trying to get me to admit to being some sort of Sorceress from Biblical times, or something like that. I told him that I knew a little about my past lives, but I didn't think I was ever a sorceress. Normally, people are just ordinary people in their past lives. So many people claim to be the reincarnation of Cleopatra or somebody famous. I'm just me. I was just me. Nobody special. But, other than that bit of weirdness, we connected on a lot of different levels. It was...breathtaking.
output: Breathtaking?

instruction: Yeah! It was amazing! We just spent all night jabbering away like old friends. It was very neat-o. Anyhow, we remembered the concept of time about four in the morning and we both freaked out. Luke was going to be mad at me, and Peter has this whacked out girlfriend-type person that would be mad at him. He kept insisting that she wasn't not his girlfriend--she's his Guru. Yeah, right. So we parted company, and I gave him my e-mail address. I'm waiting for him to write me. He needs my help with that wacko girlfriend--Guru--of his. After all, I am a Wiccan Priestess. So I'm going to help. It's my duty.
